election_record.label: Pennsylvania 1814 Governor

overview.note: George Latimer is also listed as George Lattimore.

During the War of 1812, there was some British military movement in and around the Chesapeake Bay area and in an attempt to prepare for any military actions that the British might take, there were a host of military camps set up in some of the counties close to the Chesapeake Bay and Philadelphia City. In the October 1814 Pennsylvania state elections, the members of the military camps native to Pennsylvania were allowed to vote. When the newspapers reported these returns they listed them under "camp" or "army" votes. Often times, it is not clear how many army votes were counted in the Official Returns. Residents of the camps may have come from different counties and there are times when some of the camp votes for Governor were not counted.

The American Volunteer (Carlisle, PA) from February 2, 1815 lists 1456 votes for Simon Snyder and 349 votes for Isaac Wayne in "General Watson's Division." It also lists 3350 votes for Simon Snyder and 949 votes for Isaac Wayne in "Generals Worrell's and Scheetz's Divisions," but does not say where they were cast.
Several sources list George Latimer with 910 votes. These sources do not include the 14 votes for Latimer reported in Allegheny County.

sub_unit.name: Allegheny
sub_unit.note: "In Butler county, for instance, Mr. Snyder received 206 federal votes, in Allegheny county 200, and in Westmoreland 500, because it was not generally known that Mr. Wayne would serve." Norfolk Gazette and Publick Ledger (Norfolk, VA). November 2, 1814.

sub_unit.name: Indiana
sub_unit.note: The votes cast in Jefferson County are included in the returns from Indiana County.
The Delaware Gazette (Wilmington, DE) from November 1, 1814 lists 433 votes for Simon Snyder in Indiana and Jefferson Counties.
The Boston Daily Advertiser (Boston, MA) and Repertory from October 29, 1814 lists 433 votes for Simon Snyder in Indiana and Jefferson Counties.

The Boston Daily Advertiser (Boston, MA) and Repertory from October 29, 1814 lists "The nomination of Isaac Wayne being unknown in the Counties of Jefferson and Indiana, there were 127 votes for George Latimer." Poulson's American Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) from October 24, 1814 states the same.

sub_unit.name: Beaver
sub_unit.note: The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA) from October 29, 1814 lists 832 votes for Simon Snyder in Beaver county.

sub_unit.name: Bedford
sub_unit.note: The Northumberl. Republicaner, und Northumberland, Union und Columbia Counties Adverteiser (Sunbury, PA) from October 29, 1814 lists 349 votes for Isaac Wayne in Bedford County.

sub_unit.name: Berks
sub_unit.note: Several sources list Simon Snyder with 2016 votes and Isaac Wayne with 1801 votes. These are early totals from Berks County, but do not include the additional votes from military camps.

sub_unit.name: Military
sub_unit.note: The Susquehanna Democrat (Wilkes-Barre, PA) from January 13, 1815 lists 551 military votes for Simon Snyder and 106 military votes for Isaac Wayne in Berks and Schuylkill Counties, combined.

The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from September 11, 1815 lists 210 military votes for Simon Snyder and 59 military votes for Isaac Wayne cast by "1st Regiment 2nd Brigade, Lieutenant Colonel Shappol" in Berks and Schuylkill Counties.

The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from September 11, 1815 lists 273 military votes for Simon Snyder and 36 military votes for Isaac Wayne cast by "2nd Regiment 2nd Brigade, Lieutenant Colonel Lotz" in Berks and Schuylkill Counties.

sub_unit.name: Captains Peter's, Snyder's, and Hahn's Companies, Lieutenant Colonel Ritscher
Bradford
sub_unit.note: The Northumberl. Republicaner, und Northumberland, Union und Columbia Counties Adverteiser (Sunbury, PA) from October 29, 1814 lists 231 votes for Simon Snyder, but this is likely a printing error.
Some votes cast in Bradford County are included in the Lycoming County returns.

sub_unit.name: Bucks
sub_unit.note: These totals are reported in both the Journal of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives and Journal of the Pennsylvania State Senate. They are lower than other reported totals and may reflect amendments to the official camp votes.
Pennsylvania Correspondent, and Farmers' Advertiser (Doylestown, PA) from October 24, 1814 lists Simon Snyder with 2485 votes and Isaac Wayne with 2066 votes.

The Boston Daily Advertiser (Boston, MA) and Repertory from October 29, 1814 lists 2481 votes for Simon Snyder and 2065 votes for Isaac Wayne, not including the votes cast by the riflemen commanded by Captains Magill and Purdy.

sub_unit.name: Military Camp
sub_unit.note: The military votes included under Bucks County were cast at the Bush Hill and Marcus-Hook camps. Pennsylvania Correspondent, and Farmers' Advertiser (Doylestown, PA). October 17, 1814. October 24, 1814.

The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from September 11, 1815 lists that Colonel Bache's Regiment cast 201 votes for Simon Snyder and 81 votes for Isaac Wayne in Bucks, Montgomery, Chester, and Lancaster counties.

sub_unit.name: Rifle Corps of Captains Magill and Purdy, Colonel Humphrey's Regiment
Butler
sub_unit.note: "In Butler county, for instance, Mr. Snyder received 206 federal votes, in Allegheny county 200, and in Westmoreland 500, because it was not generally known that Mr. Wayne would serve." Norfolk Gazette and Publick Ledger (Norfolk, VA). November 2, 1814.

sub_unit.name: Cambria
sub_unit.note: The Boston Daily Advertiser (Boston, MA) and Repertory from December 27, 1814 lists 20 votes for Isaac Wayne in Cambria County.

sub_unit.name: Centre, Clearfield and McKean Counties
sub_unit.note: The votes cast in Clearfield and McKean Counties are included in the Centre County returns.

sub_unit.name: Centre
sub_unit.note: The History of Centre and Clinton Counties lists 32 votes for Isaac Wayne.

sub_unit.name: Chester
sub_unit.note: The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from October 20, 1814 lists Simon Snyder with 2707 votes and Isaac Wayne with 3014 votes.

sub_unit.name: Military
sub_unit.note: "Another company, consisting of 42 republicans from the Manor, left Baltimore a few days before the election, but did not arrive at home in time to give their votes." The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA). October 20, 1814.
The Susquehanna Democrat (Wilkes-Barre, PA) from January 13, 1815 lists 167 military votes for Simon Snyder and 18 military votes for Isaac Wayne in Chester County.

The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from September 11, 1815 lists that Colonel Bache's Regiment cast 201 votes for Simon Snyder and 81 votes for Isaac Wayne in Bucks, Montgomery, Chester, and Lancaster counties.

sub_unit.name: Captain Holme's Rifle Company attached to Colonel Hamilton's Battalion of Riflemen
Military
sub_unit.note: In the counties of Columbia, Northumberland, and Union, Simon Snyder received 311 military votes and Isaac Wayne received 63 military votes from Lieutenant Colonel Weirich's Regiment.

sub_unit.name: Kritzer's
sub_unit.note: The Carlisle Herald (Carlisle, PA) from October 28, 1814 lists 73 votes for Isaac Wayne in Kritzer's.
Kline's Weekly Carlisle Gazette (Carlisle, PA) from October 21, 1814 lists 73 votes for Isaac Wayne in Kritzer's.

sub_unit.name: Toboyne
sub_unit.note: The Carlisle Herald (Carlisle, PA) from October 28, 1814 and Kline's Weekly Carlisle Gazette (Carlisle, PA) from October 21, 1814 report 62 votes for Isaac Wayne in Toboyne.

sub_unit.name: Military
sub_unit.note: The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA) from October 22, 1814 lists Simon Snyder with 342 military votes and Isaac Wayne with 70 military votes.
The Susquehanna Democrat (Wilkes-Barre, PA) from January 13, 1815 lists 309 military votes for Simon Snyder and 74 military votes for Isaac Wayne in Dauphin County.

sub_unit.name: Captains Graham's, Featherhoft's, Snyder's, Detrick's, and Todd's Companies attached to the 2nd Regiment 1st Brigade, Lieutenant Colonel Ritscher
Captains Walker's, Moorhead's, Crain's, Elder's, Knight's, and Carother's Companies attached to the 1st Regiment 1st Brigade, Colonel Kennedy
Delaware
sub_unit.note: The Delaware Gazette (Wilmington, DE) from November 1, 1814 lists a majority of 649 votes for Isaac Wayne in Delaware County.

sub_unit.name: Erie and Warren
sub_unit.note: Votes from Warren County are included in the returns from Erie County.

sub_unit.name: Fayette
sub_unit.note: The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA) from October 29, 1814 lists 1582 votes for Simon Snyder in Fayette County.

sub_unit.name: Franklin
sub_unit.note: The Delaware Gazette (Wilmington, DE) from November 1, 1814, The Boston Daily Advertiser (Boston, MA) and Repertory from October 29, 1814, and the Adams Centinel (Gettysburg, PA) from October 19, 1814 list 1307 votes for Isaac Wayne.

sub_unit.name: Huntingdon
sub_unit.note: Several sources list Isaac Wayne with 89 votes, however both the Journal of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives and Journal of the Pennsylvania State Senate lists Wayne with 83 votes in Huntingdon County.

sub_unit.name: Hollidaysburg
sub_unit.note: The Huntingdon Gazette (Huntingdon, PA) and The Huntingdon Gazette (Huntingdon, PA), both from October 20, 1814, report 89 votes for Isaac Wayne in the Hollidaysburg district of Huntingdon County. The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from October 28, 1814 and The Delaware Gazette (Wilmington, DE) from November 1, 1814 just states that the 89 votes were in Huntingdon County.

sub_unit.name: Lancaster
sub_unit.note: The Boston Daily Advertiser (Boston, MA) and Repertory from October 29, 1814 lists 2942 votes for Simon Snyder and 2952 votes for Isaac Wayne in Lancaster County.

sub_unit.name: Military
sub_unit.note: The Susquehanna Democrat (Wilkes-Barre, PA) from January 13, 1815 lists 290 military votes for Simon Snyder and 100 military votes for Isaac Wayne in Lancaster County.

The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from September 11, 1815 reports that Colonel Bache's Regiment cast 201 votes for Simon Snyder and 81 votes for Isaac Wayne in Bucks, Montgomery, Chester, and Lancaster counties.

sub_unit.name: Captain Musser's Company of Lancaster Riflemen
Military
sub_unit.note: The Der Libanoner Morgenstern (Lebanon, PA) from October 22, 1814 lists 41 military votes for Isaac Wayne in Lebanon County.
The Susquehanna Democrat (Wilkes-Barre, PA) from January 13, 1815 lists 57 military votes for Isaac Wayne in Lebanon County.

sub_unit.name: Lehigh
sub_unit.note: The Der Northampton Correspondent (Easton, PA) from October 21, 1814 and The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA) from November 5, 1814 report 667 votes for Simon Snyder and 590 votes for Isaac Wayne in Lehigh County.

sub_unit.name: Luzerne
sub_unit.note: The Northumberl. Republicaner, und Northumberland, Union und Columbia Counties Adverteiser (Sunbury, PA) from October 29, 1814 lists 675 votes for Isaac Wayne in Luzerne County.

sub_unit.name: Lycoming
sub_unit.note: Some votes cast in Bradford County are included in the Lycoming County returns.

sub_unit.name: Military
sub_unit.note: The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from September 11, 1815 reports that Colonel Bache's Regiment cast 201 votes for Simon Snyder and 81 votes for Isaac Wayne in Bucks, Montgomery, Chester, and Lancaster counties.

sub_unit.name: Northampton
sub_unit.note: The Pennsylvania Correspondent, and Farmers' Advertiser (Doylestown, PA) from October 17, 1814 and Der Northampton Correspondent from October 21, 1814 report 1370 votes for Simon Snyder and 696 votes for Isaac Wayne in Northampton County.

sub_unit.name: Military
sub_unit.note: The Susquehanna Democrat (Wilkes-Barre, PA) from January 13, 1815 lists 134 military votes for Simon Snyder and 58 military votes for Isaac Wayne in Northampton and Pike Counties.

The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from September 11, 1815 reports that the detachments commanded by Lieutenant Colonel Christopher J. Hunter cast 134 votes for Simon Snyder and 53 votes for Isaac Wayne in Northampton and Pike Counties.

sub_unit.name: Military
sub_unit.note: In the counties of Columbia, Northumberland, and Union, Simon Snyder received 311 military votes and Isaac Wayne received 63 military votes from Lieutenant Colonel Weirich's Regiment.

sub_unit.name: Philadelphia
sub_unit.note: The United States' Gazette (Philadelphia, PA) from October 17, 1814 lists 4573 votes for Simon Snyder and 5674 votes for Isaac Wayne in Philadelphia County and Philadelphia City, including 1123 military votes for Snyder and 498 military votes for Wayne.

Poulson's American Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) from October 17, 1814 lists 4573 votes for Simon Snyder and 5674 votes for Isaac Wayne in Philadelphia County and Philadelphia City, including 1123 military votes for Snyder and 498 military votes for Wayne.
The Boston Daily Advertiser (Boston, MA) and Repertory from October 29, 1814 lists 4572 votes for Simon Snyder and 5674 votes for Isaac Wayne in Philadelphia City and Philadelphia County.

sub_unit.name: Military
sub_unit.note: The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from September 11, 1815 reports that the "Battalion of the 1st Brigade 1st Division Lieutenant Colonel Berry" cast 87 votes for Simon Snyder and 30 votes for Isaac Wayne in Philadelphia City and Philadelphia County.

The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from September 11, 1815 reports that the "Volunteers, Camp Marcus Hook, Major Sparks" cast 115 votes for Simon Snyder and 43 votes for Isaac Wayne in Philadelphia City and Philadelphia County.
The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from September 11, 1815 reports that "Camp Mount Bull" cast 24 votes for Isaac Wayne in Philadelphia City and Philadelphia County.

sub_unit.name: First Regiment of Pennsylvania Volunteers
sub_unit.note: This was also known as Colonel Biddle's Regiment.

sub_unit.name: North
sub_unit.note: The United States' Gazette (Philadelphia, PA) from October 12, 1814 lists Simon Snyder with 253 votes.

sub_unit.name: Philadelphia
sub_unit.note: The United States' Gazette (Philadelphia, PA) from October 17, 1814 lists 4573 votes for Simon Snyder and 5674 votes for Isaac Wayne as the combined total for Philadelphia County and Philadelphia City, including 1123 military votes for Snyder and 498 military votes for Wayne.

Poulson's American Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) from October 17, 1814 lists 4573 votes for Simon Snyder and 5674 votes for Isaac Wayne as the combined total for Philadelphia County and Philadelphia City, including 1123 military votes for Snyder and 498 military votes for Wayne.
The Boston Daily Advertiser (Boston, MA) and Repertory from October 29, 1814 lists 4572 votes for Simon Snyder and 5674 votes for Isaac Wayne in Philadelphia City and Philadelphia County.

sub_unit.name: Military
sub_unit.note: The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from September 11, 1815 reports that the "Battalion of the 1st Brigade 1st Division Lieutenant Colonel Berry" cast 87 votes for Simon Snyder and 30 votes for Isaac Wayne in Philadelphia City and Philadelphia County.

The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from September 11, 1815 reports that the "Volunteers, Camp Marcus Hook, Major Sparks" cast 115 votes for Simon Snyder and 43 votes for Isaac Wayne in Philadelphia City and Philadelphia County.
The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from September 11, 1815 reports that "Camp Mount Bull" cast 24 votes for Isaac Wayne in Philadelphia City and Philadelphia County.

sub_unit.name: Camp Marcus Hook
sub_unit.note: The troops in Camp Marcus Hook were also listed as Colonel Thompson's Regiment.

sub_unit.name: Northern Liberties
sub_unit.note: The Freeman's Journal and Columbian Chronicle (Philadelphia, PA) from October 14, 1814 and Poulson's American Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) from October 12, 1814 report 695 votes for Simon Snyder and 1026 votes for Isaac Wayne in Northern Liberties Township.

sub_unit.name: Pike
sub_unit.note: The Susquehanna Democrat (Wilkes-Barre, PA) from January 13, 1815 lists 134 military votes for Simon Snyder and 58 military votes for Isaac Wayne in Northampton and Pike Counties.

The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from September 11, 1815 reports that the detachments commanded by Lieutenant Colonel Christopher J. Hunter cast 134 votes for Simon Snyder and 53 votes for Isaac Wayne in Northampton and Pike Counties.

sub_unit.name: Schuylkill
sub_unit.note: Several sources list Simon Snyder with 611 votes and Isaac Wayne with 86 votes. These are early totals from Schuylkill County, but do not include the additional votes from military camps.

sub_unit.name: Military
sub_unit.note: The Susquehanna Democrat (Wilkes-Barre, PA) from January 13, 1815 lists 551 military votes for Simon Snyder and 106 military votes for Isaac Wayne in Berks and Schuylkill Counties.

The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from September 11, 1815 lists 210 military votes for Simon Snyder and 59 military votes for Isaac Wayne cast by "1st Regiment 2nd Brigade, Lieutenant Colonel Shappol" in Berks and Schuylkill Counties.

The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from September 11, 1815 lists 273 military votes for Simon Snyder and 36 military votes for Isaac Wayne cast by "2nd Regiment 2nd Brigade, Lieutenant Colonel Lotz" in Berks and Schuylkill Counties.

sub_unit.name: Tioga and Potter
sub_unit.note: The votes cast in Potter County are included in the returns attributed solely to Tioga County in many sources.

sub_unit.name: Military
sub_unit.note: The military votes for Union County were cast by the militia encamped at Bush Hill.
In the counties of Columbia, Northumberland, and Union, Simon Snyder received 311 military votes and Isaac Wayne received 63 military votes from Lieutenant Colonel Weirich's Regiment.

sub_unit.name: Washington
sub_unit.note: The Northumberl. Republicaner, und Northumberland, Union und Columbia Counties Adverteiser (Sunbury, PA) from October 29, 1814 lists 2201 votes for Simon Snyder in Washington County.

sub_unit.name: Middletown
sub_unit.note: The Reporter (Washington, PA) from October 17, 1814 lists these votes from Urie's.

sub_unit.name: Morris
sub_unit.note: The Reporter (Washington, PA) from October 17, 1814 lists these votes from Goble's.

sub_unit.name: West Bethlehem
sub_unit.note: The Reporter (Washington, PA) from October 17, 1814 lists these votes from Corkle's.

sub_unit.name: Westmoreland
sub_unit.note: "In Butler county, for instance, Mr. Snyder received 206 federal votes, in Allegheny county 200, and in Westmoreland 500, because it was not generally known that Mr. Wayne would serve." Norfolk Gazette and Publick Ledger (Norfolk, VA). November 2, 1814.
